course.subject: ACCT
course.name: Advanced Financial Accounting
course.description: Addresses accounting issues associated with (1) intercorporate investment activity that conveys significant influence or control and (2) cross-border activities.  The core topics addressed are business combinations, consolidated financial statements, associated companies, and foreign currency issues.

reviews.author: Sss
reviews.title: conso, conso, conso......
reviews.comment_content: Compulsory course for ACCT major. Covers more advanced financial accounting concepts such as consolidated financial statements and different kinds of journal entries required (for consolidated assets, liabilities, equity) when mergers and acquisitions happen. Some small parts like EPS, indirect and mutual holdings will also be discussed.
reviews.comment_teaching: Peter is a very nice professor. He always tries his best to answer the questions and explain the concepts. However, as this was the very first time he taught the course, he was not very familiar with the course materials and sometimes made some mistakes in the class. He may also speed up when he found that he did not have enough time to teach (and then cannot explain the concepts clearly...). Nevertheless, Peter has shown his passion in teaching and worked hard to explain those complex entries and concepts. :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading should be quite good, as the mean of ACCT compulsory course is around B.

Grading Scheme:
Group Exercises: 15%
Midterm: 40%
Final: 45%
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not heavy as there is no project/presentation. Almost every lesson the prof. gives a 1-2 pages group exercise and you can use it to revise what you have learnt, and won't cost you much time to finish.

The midterm is closed-book exam but the final one is open-book. The level of difficulty is moderate and as long as you have tried the questions in the textbook, you shall be fine. All in all, accounting is a subject which requires lots of practice and understanding and practice makes perfect.

reviews.author: sasannnl
reviews.title: Advanced Financial Accounting
reviews.comment_content:
The content is about advanced financial accounting.
CH1 Business Combinations
CH2 Stock Investments—Investor Accounting and Reporting
CH3 An Introduction to Consolidated Financial Statements
CH4 Consolidation Techniques and Procedures
CH5 Intercompany Profit Transactions—Inventories
==============Midterm==============

reviews.comment_teaching: His mainland accent is very strong. And only around 10 out of 70 students attended the class. I think it is also because we can watch the video recording. But definitely you can study the content by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite good.

Individual Assignment 15%, Me 83/85 (Almost everyone full marks)
Midterm 40%, Me: 29/32 (Mean: 27, Median: 28, SD: 3.78)
Final 45%, Unknown, but I am confident that I did very well

Finally A
reviews.comment_workload: The workload depends on your efforts. Prof suggest many exercises in the syllabus, but it is optional. If you want to get good grade, do the suggested exercises.

reviews.author: Kody
reviews.title: Practice, practice, practice
reviews.comment_content: Consolidation of financial statements; starts from very basic situations (recognizing goodwill whilst disolving subsidiary) to adjusting inter-company transactions. First 4 chapters are very important, so make sure you understand fully how the figures are calculated. Peter only teaches the basic method on how to arrive on those figures, but the textbook will elaborate on other methods.
reviews.comment_teaching: Because consolidation is very complicated, Peter encourages us to attend every lecture. He knows the concepts and methodologies well, but his English is not so good, and one can easily doze off, especially in the afternoon. He follows the PPT strictly, but he will happily answer any questions you raise throughout class. After a lot of lecturing, he will give out handouts for us to practice in-class. But his time management is not so good, so sometimes he rushes in the end.
reviews.comment_grading:
15% is awarded based on the group exercises. Peter mentioned that he would like us to finish them in-class, but in the end, he would let us take the exercises home and hand them in next class.
40% is for the mid-term, and it covered the first 5 chapters. Closed book, but can bring cheat sheet.
45% is for the final, non-cumulative. But a lot of the content after the midterm is built upon the content of previous sessions. Open-book, so label your book and notes carefully to quickly find the entries needed. Time is tight for both exams. Make sure you print the handouts and solutions too because the finals will feature the exact questions.
Peter won't fail anyone, but accounting courses are extremely competitive in UST so try your best.
reviews.comment_workload: Practice makes perfect; this is exceptionally true for accounting courses. Finish his recommended exercises at the end of the textbook and you'll be fine.

reviews.author: Tasha
reviews.title: Hard, but not that much
reviews.comment_content:
Very useful in the current business world, hard as well.
Be careful that you don't pile up your questions or it would become a heavy burden that crushes you in exams, especially for the final.
reviews.comment_teaching: Kind of detailed teaching with examples, at least good for me.
reviews.comment_grading: Reasonable grading, the mid-term questions are all easy MCQs, but the final ones changed to written, and were much harder, but should be ok if followed.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 asg
1 mid-term
1 final

Very light workload if you only want a B or so, or you are smart to learn only once and understand it all. If not, spend a little bit more time to review and practice.

reviews.author: Account guy
reviews.comment_content: This course is about consolidation which mainly focuses things which have not been covered in ACCT 3020. However, this course is much easier than ACCT 3020. I believe this might be the easiest accounting course which requires numbering although this might be the last accounting course for many students.

reviews.comment_workload: Workload is light and manageable. Only assignments, mid term and final.

reviews.author: UST1234
reviews.comment_content:
first half of the course was manageable, preparing into the Consolidation topic, not too hard I would say

second half of the course was harder, all about Consolidation, you must have solid knowledge on the first half of the course before moving into the second half of the course

assignments were no brainer, you can find all the answers on the Internet, just make sure you hand them in
reviews.comment_teaching:
He's a kind professor, willing to answer questions from students. He would ask if any one got lost during classes and explain further.
He responded to emails quite often (before final exam).
I think he explains quite well and he knows the Accounting so well that when I asked him questions that I myself couldn't articulate well, he understood.

One big fault in this course is the answer key for the textbook questions. There is like minimum 1 error per chapter. Students tried to send him emails and correct them, well he would respond to the earlier ones but not the latter ones probably because there were too many emails.
reviews.comment_grading:
Work hard pays off.
I did all the textbook questions over and over again and went to the professor when I had doubts.

assignments 15%
mid term 40%
final 45%

my marks were:
100% on assignments
100/110 for midterm
??? for final

got A+ in the end

I feel that the mid term was more difficult than the final either because I wasn't that familiar with Consolidation in the beginning or Prof was lenient for the final exam. I think the latter is true though cuz many of us left early for the final (though I didn't), still I heard people feel that the final was easy.

Just work as hard as you can, Accounting is all about practices, just do more you'll achieve the grade you wish.

reviews.author: You guess!
reviews.title: Most interesting course in UST
reviews.comment_content:
All about consolidation issues, like inter-company transactions, different reporting currencies and indirect holding.
(Refer to attached course syllabus for details)

Some of my friends said the content is hard af, but I think the content is sort of straight-forward and interesting, as long as you could understand the rationale behind the concept.

Btw, I am just a Year 3 student and I haven't studied ACCT3010 and ACCT3020, thus some concepts may find me difficult to understand at the beginning (e.g. diluted EPS and unrealized profit)
reviews.comment_teaching: To be honest, his accent is hard to understand. HOWEVER, he is sooooo nice that he always wills to answer students' question. I often ask him questions during his office hour and he is very patient to answer.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade!

Assignment (15%): 5 assignments in total, basically you can find answers online, so the mean is almost full for each assignment.

Midterm (40%) & Final (45%): All MCQ (35-36 questions in 2 hours), most questions are really easy, but some are tricky.

My Score:
Assignment: Full mark
Midterm: Full mark
Final: Didn't disclose
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Workload only depends on how much effort you paid to the course. If you did all suggested questions in textbook (around 10 per chapter), then workload would be a bit high as some questions are usually quite hard, but overall workload is not high.
